items.name: Salmon
items.notes: Rich in omega-3s, great for baby's brain development. Limit to 2-3 servings per week.

items.name: Shrimp
items.notes: Low mercury, high protein. Cook thoroughly to 145°F (63°C).

items.name: Canned Light Tuna
items.notes: Lower in mercury than albacore. Limit to 6oz (170g) per week.

items.name: Raw Sushi/Sashimi
items.notes: Risk of parasites and bacteria. Stick to cooked rolls or vegetarian options.

items.name: High Mercury Fish
items.notes: Avoid shark, swordfish, king mackerel, and tilefish due to high mercury levels.

items.name: Raw Oysters/Shellfish
items.notes: Risk of Vibrio bacteria and other pathogens. Always eat fully cooked.

items.name: Pasteurized Milk
items.notes: Great source of calcium and vitamin D. Choose pasteurized products only.

items.name: Hard Cheeses
items.notes: Cheddar, parmesan, and swiss are safe even if made from unpasteurized milk.

items.name: Well-Cooked Eggs
items.notes: Cook until both yolk and white are firm. Great protein source.

items.name: Yogurt (Pasteurized)
items.notes: Excellent source of probiotics and calcium. Choose pasteurized varieties.

items.name: Soft Cheeses (Unpasteurized)
items.notes: Brie, camembert, blue cheese may contain listeria unless pasteurized.

items.name: Raw or Runny Eggs
items.notes: Risk of salmonella. Avoid homemade mayo, mousse, and raw cookie dough.

items.name: Raw/Unpasteurized Milk
items.notes: May contain harmful bacteria including listeria. Always choose pasteurized.

items.name: Well-Done Meat
items.notes: Cook beef, pork, lamb to 160°F (71°C) internal temperature.

items.name: Fully Cooked Poultry
items.notes: Cook chicken and turkey to 165°F (74°C). Great lean protein source.

items.name: Heated Deli Meat
items.notes: Heat deli meats until steaming (165°F/74°C) to kill potential listeria.

items.name: Rare/Medium Rare Meat
items.notes: Undercooked meat may contain harmful bacteria. Cook thoroughly.

items.name: Cold Deli Meats
items.notes: Risk of listeria contamination. Heat until steaming before eating.

items.name: Pâté & Meat Spreads
items.notes: Refrigerated pâté may contain listeria. Canned versions are safer.

items.name: Liver
items.notes: Contains very high levels of vitamin A which can harm the baby.

items.name: Washed Fresh Produce
items.notes: Wash all fruits and vegetables thoroughly. Great for vitamins and fiber.

items.name: Cooked Vegetables
items.notes: Cooking eliminates any surface bacteria. Safe and nutritious.

items.name: Pasteurized Juice
items.notes: Choose pasteurized juices. Fresh-squeezed at home is also safe.

items.name: Raw Sprouts
items.notes: Alfalfa, bean, and other sprouts may harbor bacteria. Cook before eating.

items.name: Unpasteurized Juice
items.notes: Fresh juices from juice bars may not be pasteurized. Ask first.

items.name: Water
items.notes: Stay hydrated! Aim for 8-10 glasses daily. Filtered or bottled is best.

items.name: Safe Herbal Teas
items.notes: Ginger, peppermint, and citrus teas are generally safe in moderation.

items.name: Coffee/Tea (Limited)
items.notes: Keep caffeine under 200mg/day (about one 12oz coffee).

items.name: Alcohol
items.notes: No amount of alcohol is safe during pregnancy. Avoid completely.

items.name: Certain Herbal Teas
items.notes: Avoid licorice root, dong quai, and other medicinal herbs. Ask your doctor.

items.name: Energy Drinks
items.notes: High caffeine and other stimulants. Not safe during pregnancy.

items.name: Tofu & Legumes
items.notes: Excellent plant-based protein sources. Cook tofu thoroughly.

items.name: Nuts & Seeds
items.notes: Great source of healthy fats and protein (unless you have allergies).

items.name: Honey
items.notes: Safe for pregnant women. Not safe for babies under 1 year.

items.name: Artificial Sweeteners
items.notes: Aspartame and sucralose are considered safe in moderation. Limit saccharin.

items.name: Unwashed Produce
items.notes: Always wash fruits and vegetables to remove bacteria and pesticides.
